Tang Dynasty, Funiushan, Luoyang, Biography of Jizai, Tang Dynasty, Funiushan, Luoyang, Biography of Jizai, One-bowl Monk, Nan Yin Shi Jizai, secular surname Li, from Wuxing, had extraordinary auspicious signs at birth.
When he grew up, he sat in full lotus posture, and his relatives regarded him as unusual.
He bid farewell to his loved ones and left to become a monk on Jingshan, and received full ordination in Xin Ding.

When he studied with various masters, he attended the Dharma seat of Chan Master Daoyi of Nankang, had a profound understanding of the true teaching, and his free spirit was unmatched by his peers. His reputation as a Chan master was widely known, and his conduct was leisurely.
He often stayed in the mountains and valleys, and Chan practitioners from all directions gathered at his gate.
During the Yuanhe period, he lived on Xiangshan in Luoyang, and was close friends with Chan Master Tianran.
Wherever he went, he would always enjoy the ancient sites, wishing to obtain the traces of past sages to delight in his observations.
At Longmen Mountain, he found the place where the Tripiá¹­aka master of the Later Wei translated scriptures;
At Wangwu Mountain, he found the place where Chan Master ChÅu subdued a fighting tiger, and drank sweet spring water there, renaming it Ganquan Temple;
At Mount Song, he found the horse-running spring of Master Fan.
He did not cling to dwelling anywhere, and wrote the Three Wounds Song, with both its words and principles being beautiful, awakening the deluded and benefiting the times.

In the beginning of the pseudo-Qiande era of the former Shu Wang clan, a minor military commissioner Chen Gong married the granddaughter of Gao Zhongling Bian Zhusun, who had observed not killing for over twenty years. Later, in Shu, he married a man, and the ceremony required slaughtering.
Gao initially did not want to, and his relatives said:
If you yourself observe the precepts, what will you use to entertain guests at the banquet?
At the juncture of obeying and disobeying, he ended up slaughtering many animals.
Before ten days had passed, he fell ill with a strange condition. His mouth only spoke incoherently. After three nights, he revived and recounted the events in the netherworld.

At first, he was pursued and captured by black-clothed emissaries and brought into the city god temple of Qi Prefecture. The temple god, wearing a towering hat and wide sleeves, was seated with a golden-armored warrior.
The emissaries led Gao to see the god. The warrior spoke in a flurry, arguing that Gao had broken the precepts. He then grabbed Gao's arm and scolded:
I am the deity who guards the precepts.
For twenty years, you have eaten and slept without leisure. How could I expect you to suddenly give rise to murderous thoughts and abruptly violate the precepts?
Although your life is not yet over, your crimes are quite grave. You must be sent to the underworld to punish your past offenses.
The city god asked Gao:

What good deeds have you cultivated to redeem your past faults?ğŸ”½Gao always recited the Sutra on Rebirth in the Pure Land many times, but at that time he was completely oblivious and had no recollection. In his fear, he said:
I have recited the Sutra on Rebirth in the Pure Land many times.
I have memorized the Three Wounds Sutra and the Song of the One-Bowl Monk.

He then joined his palms together, faced the deity, and recited it with a loud voice. The deity and the warriors cocked their ears and stood listening with fists raised. Their expressions gradually brightened.
When the chapter ended, the deity all wept. He then said to Gao:
Go back to the human world and diligently do good deeds.
Before he finished paying his respects, Gao suddenly sat up and fully recounted what had happened.
From then on, the songs of the Three Wounds and the One-Bowl Monk were all copied and recited by people.

As for the One-Bowl Monk, the lyrics accord with the principles and deeply encourage one to worry and think. However, the literary style involves the alleys, how can it compare to the elegance of the Three Wounds?
He told his disciples to go to Jiangnan and select the most scenic places, saying, I wish to go there to end my old age.
When they arrived at Douchang County in Jiangzhou, there was a beautiful forest and spring, so they reported back.
When he arrived at Xing and Yexian, he was detained by the monks and laypeople.
He passed away at Kaiyuan Temple in Suizhou at the age of 81, in the first year of the Longxing era.
The author says:
Examining the Vinaya scriptures, if one who has left the household life commits an offense, they will incur two offenses: one is violating the precepts, and the other is karmic retribution.

Gao was a layperson and had not yet received the precepts, so he did not have the offense of violating the precepts. He may have had the offense of karmic retribution in his secular form, but how could he have the spirit that protects the precepts?
Moreover, since Gao upheld the precept against killing, he was mysteriously moved to stop and the wholesome karma of upholding the precepts arose in him.
Because he was not able to fully uphold it, he encountered a ghostly accusation. He warned the five groups of Buddhist followers to fear the spirit that protects the precepts.
If it is like this, then in the light there are the precepts, and in the dark there are ghosts and spirits.
Next, Shi Nan Yin of Yuanhe Shengshou Temple in Chengdu Prefecture, whose surname was Zhang.
He had a nature of enlightenment and was never tired of receiving benefits. He attained the profound meaning of Caoxi but had nothing to prove it.
He saw Master Hui of Jingzhong Temple, who was like brocade that shines even more when washed, or a candle-dragon that illuminates the darkness as it moves.

Yin came from Jiangling to Sichuan, where he cleared the grass and built a thatched hut to the south of the Shu River. The assembly all looked up to him, and gradually a Buddhist abode was formed, in the early years of the Zhenyuan era.
Gao, the Minister of Works, after subduing Liu Piji, renamed the temple Yuanhe Shengshou, originally named Baoying.
Yin's transformative work was about to end, and in the early years of the Changqing era, he showed signs of illness and entered nirvana.
A stupa was built to bury him in the temple.
During the Huichang era, the stupa was destroyed, but during the Dazhong era, it was rebuilt on the old site of Baoying to the north of the river, and the temple was renamed Shengshou again.
Yin's disciple Chuansi Yimian revived the Chan teachings there.
The Biography of Wuye of Kaiyuan Temple in Fenzhou, Tang Dynasty. The Biography of Wuye of Kaiyuan Temple in Fenzhou, Tang Dynasty. Shi Wuye, whose surname was Du, was from Shangluo in Shangzhou.
His mother, Lady Li, suddenly heard a voice in the air saying:
Can you accommodate a guest?
Soon after, she became pregnant.
On the evening of his birth, strange light filled the room.
When he grew up, he did not play around. When walking, he walked straight ahead. When sitting, he sat with his legs crossed.
When he was shown to the monks, they all marveled, saying, This is an unsurpassed Dharma vessel. Quickly let him leave home and continue the Three Jewels.

When he reached the age of nine, he asked his parents to allow him to rely on Chan Master Zhiben of Kaiyuan Temple in his own prefecture. He was then taught the Diamond Sutra, the Lotus Sutra, the Vimalakirti Sutra, the Sutra of Contemplating Benevolence, the Flower Ornament Sutra, and other sutras. He recited all of them without missing a single word.
At the age of twelve, he was allowed to shave his head.ğŸ”½Wherever he went to study, he understood as soon as he heard it.
When his classmates did not understand something, he would analyze it for them, all reaching the profound gate.
At the age of twenty, he received full ordination from Vinaya Master You of Xiangzhou. In one summer, he studied and could expound the Four Part Vinaya Commentary.

He also lectured on the Nirvana Sutra for the monastic assembly. The Dharma seat was always open, without weariness in winter or summer. It can be said that Sengzhao was not obliterated, and Lin and Yuan were revived.
Later, he heard that the Great Silence of Hongzhou was the foremost in the Chan gate, and he went specially to pay respects.
His body was over six feet tall, standing upright like a mountain, and his gaze was always fixed, his voice sounding like a great bell.
The Great Silence saw him as extraordinary and smiled, saying:
The majestic Buddha hall, but there is no Buddha inside.
Then, Fa-ye bowed and knelt, saying:
As for the literature of the Three Vehicles, I have roughly exhausted their meaning.
I have heard that in the Chan gate, the mind itself is the Buddha, but I truly have not been able to understand it.
The Great Silence said:
The mind that has not yet been understood is precisely it, there is no other thing.
If you do not understand time, you are deluded.
If you do understand, you are enlightened.
Delusion is sentient beings, and enlightenment is Buddha.
The Way is not separate from sentient beings, how could there be a separate Buddha?
It is just like making a fist with the hand, the fist is the whole hand.
As soon as he heard this, [Huai]yan suddenly became enlightened. He wept tears of sorrow and said to Mazu:
Previously I thought that the Buddha Way was long and far, and that it took countless kalpas of hard work to finally achieve it.
Today I have just realized that the Dharma body's true nature is originally complete, and all myriad dharmas arise from the mind. They are merely names and have no reality.
Mazu said:
It is just as you say. The nature of all dharmas is neither arising nor ceasing. All dharmas are originally empty and tranquil.
The sutra says:
'All dharmas, from the very beginning, are always characterized by quiescent extinction.'
It also says:
'The house of ultimate emptiness and tranquility.'
It also says:ğŸ”½'The nature of all dharmas is originally quiescent.'
The seat of all dharmas is emptiness.
This is where the buddhas and tathÄgatas abide in the abode of non-abiding.
If one knows thus, one abides in the abode of emptiness and sits on the seat of the emptiness of dharmas, not leaving the place of practice whether raising or lowering the foot.
Understanding it directly, there is no more gradual approach. This is called ascending the mountain of nirvÄá¹‡a without moving one's feet.

After transmitting the mind seal, [Daoxin] visited the ancestral pagoda of Caoxi and, on his return, traveled to Mount Lu, Mount Heng, Mount Tiantai, and other famous mountains, visiting all the sacred sites.
From Luoyang he went to Chang'an and stayed at Ximing Temple. The monks all wanted to recommend him to be one of the great virtuous ones of the two capitals, but Daoxin remained silent and sighed:
Associating with kings and ministers is not my intention!

Then he arrived in Shangdang. The Censor-in-Chief Li Baoying and the Military Commissioner Ma Sui had repeatedly made military achievements, and they also inspired Wang Wujun to jointly defeat Zhautou. Although their merits were many and their power was great, they loved to hear about virtuous and good people. Even if they were a thousand miles away, they would definitely send envoys to invite them.
They deeply respected Yixing's reputation and name, and they looked up to him day and night. Their banners came and went.
He always had a tired look and said to his disciples:
I originally avoided the vast fame and profit of the imperial court. Now this is also troublesome to meet with the lords. How could this be my intention!
After saying this, he leisurely went to Baofu Mountain in Mian.
He also went to Mount Wutai and read the Buddhist canon at the Golden Pavilion Temple. He completed his vow after eight circulations of the stars in the sky.
He then shook his staff and went south, arriving in Xihe. He first stayed at the Buddhist temple of Zhongxiang. The prefect Dong Shuchuan invited him to stay at Kaiyuan Temple.
Since I came here, I no longer have the intention to travel around. Could it be that my karmic affinity is here?
Then he struck the bell to inform the assembly, roared like a lion, rained down the great Dharma rain, and stayed for twenty years.
The people of Bingzhou and Fenzhou all turned to him for transformation.

In the fourteenth year of Emperor Xianzong's reign, he had long admired his virtuous reputation and issued an edict inviting him to the inner palace. [Yixing] declined on the grounds of illness and did not go.
The following year, another imperial decree was issued, but he still declined on the grounds of illness.

In the year of Emperor Muzong's ascension to the throne, the emperor's thoughts were sincere and he wished to see [Yixing] once. He ordered Lingzhuan, the monk registrar of the two streets, to bring an imperial decree to invite him.
When Lingzhuan arrived, he bowed and said:
I know that you, Master, are aloof from the dust of the world and disdain worldly affairs.
The Dharma is entrusted to the king of the country. Please, Master, consider this carefully!
This time the imperial decree is not like usual. I hope the Master will comply with the emperor's wishes and not decline again on the grounds of illness.
Moving in accordance with circumstances, not burdening later people.
Yefu laughed and said:
What merits do I have to trouble the sage ruler?
If I am to go, then I will go.
The paths are different.
Then he shaved his head and bathed. At midnight, he told his disciples Huiyin and others:
You see, the nature of hearing, seeing, and knowing is the same as the sky's longevity, unborn and undying.
All realms are originally empty and still, with not a single dharma to be attained.
The deluded do not understand and are deceived by objects, once deceived by objects, they wander endlessly.
You should know that the nature of the mind is originally inherent, not created by causes, like a diamond that cannot be destroyed.
All dharmas are like shadows and echoes, without reality. Therefore the sutra says:
'Only this one truth, the other two are not real.'
Always understand that everything is empty, without a single thing in the mind, this is the place where all Buddhas use the same mind.
You should diligently practice it!
After saying this, he sat in meditation and peacefully passed away.
Alas, he can truly be said to have attained mastery over birth and death!
He was 62 years old in the secular world and had been a monk for 42 years.

The monks and laypeople mourned him as if they had lost their father or mother, so they prepared incense, flowers, banners, and canopies, and moved his entire body to the west of the city to the Lianru Temple. They piled up fragrant firewood and performed the tea ceremony for cremation.

Then there were auspicious clouds from the sky, five colors condensing in the sky, and strange incense coming from the west, with a rich and fragrant atmosphere. All the officials and common people in the realm heard and saw it.
When the firewood was exhausted and the fire extinguished, they obtained Å›arÄ«ra, shining like pearls and jade.
His disciples Huiyin, Xingqin, Qianlong, Yiyous, Yuandu, Hengtai, and others.
Weeping blood, they collected it and buried it in a golden coffin.
He then ordered a skilled craftsman to carve a stone pagoda and on the twenty-first day of the twelfth month in the third year of Changqing, he was buried in the courtyard of Lianru.
In the year of Yejian's death, the state governor Yang Qian, together with the monk registrar Jun, fully described the events and thus composed a stele inscription.
The emperor posthumously bestowed the title of Greatly Enlightened National Preceptor and the stupa was named Clear Spring.

The Biography of Shi Ruhui of Dongsi Temple in Changsha during the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Shi Ruhui of Dongsi Temple in Changsha during the Tang Dynasty, Shi Ruhui was a person from Shixing, Shaozhou.
In the eighth year of Dali, he stayed under the tutelage of Chan Master Guoyi and later returned to the Dharma assembly of Great Silence.

At that time, the well spring had prematurely dried up, and strange fragrance filled the air. His pagoda was moved to the south of the city.
The censor Li Ao completely destroyed the tombs and pagodas near the city, only leaving the pagoda where Chan Master Huaihai was buried. He wrote with his brush, saying:
Only leaving this pagoda, to distinguish the wise from the foolish.

Biography of Shi Taiyu of Mount Furong in Changzhou during the Tang Dynasty. Shi Taiyu, whose surname was Fan, was a person from Jinling.
At the age of ten, he aspired to become a monk and paid homage to Chan Master Zhong of Mount Niutou as his teacher.
Thereupon, he was vigorous and diligent, seeking the profound meaning. The Dharma vessel was bright outside and the spirit was fused inside.
Although he understood the One Vehicle, he was fully endowed with myriad practices.
He went to Anguo Temple in Yongjing and received full ordination. He was outstanding among the crowd.
Moreover, his deportment was solemn, and his wondrous appearance was extraordinary, like the ocean that cannot be measured, like the sky that cannot be quantified.

He traveled to sacred sites, and his mind was pure and tranquil. Although he could understand through his own wisdom and did not need to rely on a teacher, he still needed the seal of approval and verification from a prior enlightened one.
He then visited Chan Master Dashi of Hongjing and, upon seeing his appearance, he thoroughly understood the Dharma body and instantly attained the great Way.

At that time, the Buddha Dharma was flourishing everywhere, but nowhere more so than in the prefecture of Hong. The sages and worthies under his seat were shoulder to shoulder, and the number of those who attained the Way was quite numerous.

Yu, together with Chan Master Dacheng, Chan Master Dachuan, and Chan Master Dazhi, were all brothers. They then traveled to the north and south to observe the teachings, never tiring of it, in order to broaden their knowledge and leisurely nurture their enlightened essence.
In the thirteenth year of Yuanhe, he stayed at Furong Mountain in Yixing, Jiangsu, and thus came to be known by the mountain name.

Yu acted as a condition for causes, responding without attachment, and thus those who were moved and transformed by his presence and followed him wherever he went, whether laypeople or monastics, numbered in the tens of thousands.
From then on, many people in the south of the Yangtze River awakened to the principle of Chan.
At that time, Minister of State Cui Qun was dismissed from his post for losing his seat. Later, he became the prefect of Huazhou and left Sanfeng to take up his post in Xuancheng.

Minister Cui deeply enjoyed paying respects and making sincere requests. Yuxi felt grateful and appeared, taking great compassion as his mind. He wanted to follow conditions and travel to various places, following the order.

The monks and the common people were filled with grief.
In the tenth month, he peacefully passed away in the courtyard of the monastery, in accordance with his wishes.
His disciples Zhifu, Qizhen, Qingwo, and others lamented that after their teacher's passing, the disciples remained.
In the second year of Taihe, Prime Minister Wei Chouchou, who had long admired the Way, with a sincere mind, reported the matter to the emperor.

Biography of Tancang of Xiyuan Hermitage in Nanyue, Tang Dynasty. Biography of Tancang of Xiyuan Hermitage in Nanyue, Tang Dynasty. Lingtuan Chaoan. Shi Tancang did not know where he was from. He obtained the Chan teachings from the gate of Great Silence.

In his later years, he suffered from foot problems and moved down to Xiyuan to build a thatched hut. Those who came to study were very numerous.
In the first year of Taihe, he passed away on Mount Heng at the age of seventy.

Before that, he raised a dog that was especially spiritual. Once, when he was walking at night and stopped to sit, the dog carried his robe back to his room and guarded it by the door, barking incessantly and shaking its body as if making a fierce attack.
When they looked in the morning, there was a huge python several dozen feet long in the kitchen to the east, coiled around the small hut, making it tremble.
With its mouth wide open, hissing and roaring, its poisonous breath was everywhere.
The attendants told Zang to quickly leave and avoid it, but Zang said:
If death can be escaped, what is so far away?
They come with poison, I receive with kindness.
Poison has no inherent nature, when provoked it becomes strong.
If kindness has no conditions, enemies and friends are treated the same.
No one, no self, the nature of dharmas is all empty.
As soon as he finished speaking, the python lowered its head and slowly left, disappearing in an instant.
Once, during the night, there was a group of thieves, and the dog also brought out the hidden clothes.
Zang said to the thieves:
Gentlemen, in this mountain man's thatched hut, take whatever you have a liking for, I will never begrudge even a little.
The thieves were moved by his words and dispersed, taking the goods down the mountain.
